title: R44526
content: The first section of the report outlines the FY2017 judiciary appropriations process, including key actions such as the initial request submission, hearings by House and Senate subcommittees, markups by House and Senate Appropriations Committees, House floor consideration of H.R. 5485, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017 on May 5, 2017. The status is summarized in Table 1. The FY2017 judiciary appropriations process included key actions such as the initial request submission, hearings, markups, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017 on May 5, 2017. The Budget for Fiscal Year 2017 requested $7.58 billion for judicial branch activities, including discretionary and mandatory funding for judges' salaries and benefits. The FY2017 judiciary appropriations process included key actions such as the initial request submission, hearings, markups, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017 on May 5, 2017. The House Appropriations Committee Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits. The House Appropriations Committee recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits under current law. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-18 (H.R. 5485, H.Rept. 114-624) with no amendments related to the judiciary. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $7.58 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits as required by law. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-0 (S. 3067, S.Rept. 114-280) with no amendments offered. The House agreed to a structured rule for consideration of the Financial Services and General Government bill (H.R. 5485), with an amendment reducing funding to the Salaries and Expenses Account under the Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and other Judicial Services heading by $1 million. Amendment #60 was passed by voice vote as part of an en bloc amendment. The House passed amendment #60 as part of an en bloc amendment to H.R. 5485, reducing funding to the Salaries and Expenses Account under the Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and other Judicial Services heading by $1 million. H.R. 5485, as amended, was agreed to with a vote of 239-185. No further action was taken on H.R. 5485 or S. 3067 before the start of FY2017. Judicial branch activities were funded through continuing appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017, which provided $7.5 billion for the judiciary. The Appropriations Act, 2017 (P.L. 115-31) provided $7.5 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $176.2 million from FY2016. This funding was $63.0 million less than the requested amount. The judiciary's funding for FY2016 was $7.344 billion, representing an increase of $73.9 million from FY2015. The judiciary funding for FY2015 was provided in the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015, with $7.261 billion allocated, representing a 3.2% increase from FY2014. A funding gap led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days until a CR was enacted on October 17, 2013. The government faced a funding gap leading to a partial shutdown for 16 days in October 2013. A CR was enacted on October 17, 2013, providing funding until January 15, 2014. Subsequently, a consolidated appropriations bill was passed on January 17, 2014, allocating $7.039 billion for the judiciary for FY2014. This funding accounts for approximately 0.2% of the total budget authority. The Supreme Court's funding accounts for approximately 1% of the total judiciary budget, with the majority going towards the salaries and expenses of the U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services. Other Judicial Services covers salaries of circuit and district judges, justices retired from office, judges of the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, and other officers and employees of the federal judiciary. Defender Services and Court Security are also funded. The judiciary budget is allocated to various entities within the federal court system, including the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, U.S. Court of International Trade, Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, Federal Judicial Center, U.S. Sentencing Commission, and Judicial Retirement Funds. Specialized courts like the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces, U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims, and U.S. Tax Court are funded separately. The U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims and the U.S. Tax Court are funded separately from the judiciary budget. Federal courthouse construction is funded through the General Services Administration account. Non-appropriated funds, mainly from court filing fees, help offset expenses in various judicial services accounts. The judiciary uses non-appropriated funds from court filing fees to offset expenses in various judicial services accounts. These funds are considered "unencumbered" and may be carried forward from one year to the next. Savings from the judiciary's financial plan in areas where budgeted costs did not materialize contribute to these funds. The judiciary's budget request and appropriations figures reflect net resources and do not include non-appropriated funds. "Encumbered" funds are used for delayed expenses like office space delivery and technology projects. Cost-containment efforts focus on office space rental and personnel expenses. The judiciary's cost-containment efforts focus on office space rental, personnel expenses, information technology, and operating costs. Judge Julia S. Gibbons emphasized the results of formal initiatives started in 2004 to reduce cost growth in the judiciary's budget. Judge Gibbons highlighted the judiciary's cost-containment efforts, including shared administrative services and reducing office space. The judiciary is reevaluating cost savings accounting practices in response to a GAO report. Over the past 10 years, nearly $1.5 billion in cost reductions have been achieved. Judge Gibbons reported that the judiciary has achieved a cost reduction of nearly $1.5 billion over the past 10 years. Efforts to reduce total space by 3% have resulted in $5.8 million in rent savings. The judiciary is on track to accomplish the full reduction by fiscal year 2018. Security concerns have been addressed following a double homicide of a federal judge's family members in 2005. Security concerns for judges both on-site and off-site have increased in recent years due to several incidents, including homicides and shootings. Efforts to enhance judicial security have been implemented, such as providing intrusion detection systems for judges' homes and passing the Court Security Improvement Act of 2007. The Court Security Improvement Act of 2007 aimed to enhance security for judges and court personnel, as well as courtroom safety for the public. The judiciary has been working closely with the U.S. Marshals Service to ensure protective policies are in place, including a pilot program for perimeter security at selected courthouses. The U.S. Marshals Service implemented a pilot program in 2009 to enhance perimeter security at selected courthouses, taking over from the Federal Protective Service. The program covers courthouses in Chicago, Detroit, Phoenix, New York, Tucson, and Baton Rouge. The judiciary evaluates the program biennially and reimburses USMS for protective services. The Judicial Conference of the United States recommended creating 57 new federal judgeships in March 2017, with bills introduced in Congress but no final action taken. Similar requests were made in the 114th Congress for 73 new judgeships, with subsequent legislation introduced but not finalized. The Judicial Conference recommended creating 73 new federal judgeships in the 114th Congress, but no final action was taken before adjournment. Appellate judgeships have remained at 179 since 1990, despite a 40% increase in case filings. District judgeships increased by 5% to 677, with a 38% increase in case filings. The Federal Judicial Center's FY2017 request is $28.3 million, an increase of 2.2% over the FY2016 enacted level. The center provides research, evaluation, education, and training for judges and court staff. The House-passed bill provided $28.2 million, the Senate committee-reported bill provided the full request, and P.L. 115-31 provides the full request. The Federal Judicial Center's FY2017 request is $18.2 million, an increase of 3.3% over the FY2016 enacted level. The FY2017 request for the trust funds is $161.0 million, which fluctuates with estimated retirement benefit costs. P.L. 115-31 provides full funding and includes provisions for salaries, expenses, transfers between judiciary accounts, and limitations on official expenses.
